newsitem.title: USA: Stocks weighed down by profit-taking in high techs.
newsitem.headline: Stocks weighed down by profit-taking in high techs.

text.p: Stock prices fell Tuesday as the market took its direction from the weakness in technology shares after Digital Equipment Corp. reported a bigger-than-expected loss.
At 1 p.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 33.17 points at 6,057.70, extending its retreat after setting four record high closes last week.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances 13-8 on active volume of 232 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq Composite index, a barometer of high-tech stocks, was off 18.15 points at 1,218.26. The American Stock Exchange index was off 2.03 at 574.84.
The selling was encouraged by a worse-than-expected loss by Digital, but analysts also said that technology stocks have had strong moves recently and were overextended.
"The high techs are getting a much needed near term correction," said Roy Blumberg, chief investment strategist at Josephthal Lyon & Ross.

"They have been the leaders of the move higher over the last couple of months," he said. "They've had a tremendous run and, as long as the market holds up well, they will have a correction of some 5 percent."
Blumberg said, however, that were the market to embark on a more significant downward move, technology stocks would find themselves vulnerable in the ensuing sell-off.
"Not that there is anything wrong with their fundamentals, but when people like stocks they take them too high," Blumberg said. "The techs were taken to levels at which too much is discounted."
Digital Equipment posted a deeper-than-expected loss of $65.9 million for the last three months compared with a profit of $48.2 million a year ago. The company's stock was down 5 at 29-3/8.
Other high techs followed suit, with Microsoft off 2 at 132, Intel down 2-1/2 at 105-1/4, Iomega Corp. down 1-1/2 at 21-3/4 and Micron Technology down 1-1/8 at 29-1/2.

"The market continues to consolidate last week's gains and the Nasdaq and the tech sector could continue to see considerable profit-taking," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd.

In other earnings-related news, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. rose 1-3/8 at 105-1/2 after the company reported higher-than-expected third quarter earnings. Eli Lilly, another drug maker, rose 1-1/4 to 70 on strong earnings.
